awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant, Purdue University: Center for Accurate Georeferencing of the Environment (CAGE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The global economic impact of Global Positioning System (GPS) use is estimated at ~$1B/day. GPS and resulting geospatial location information (i.e., georeferencing) serves a diverse ecosystem of companies across the spectrum of users including manufacturers, system integrators, service providers, and end users. It is a technology that has exploded in recent decades with the private sector superseding the historic dominance of U.S. federal agencies in geospatial technology development and deployment. However, this proliferation has revealed vulnerabilities due rapidly advancing technology and data analytics for both commercial and government entities. The resulting evolution and fragmentation of geospatial technologies has precipitated a need for strategic investment in foundational elements related to GPS and georeferencing. To address this issue, funding is being provided for The Ohio State University, Purdue University, and Saint Louis University to explore the formation of a three-Site industry-university cooperative research center: The Center for Accurate Georeferencing of the Environment (CAGE). The Center will generate and disseminate new foundational knowledge in three interrelated areas of potential strong interest to prospective Members. These include foundational research on GPS-based and alternative AI-based navigation and mapping technologies to advance geospatial data referencing platforms upon which commercial innovation depends; refine and work with industry to codify and adopt geospatial data standards and best practices for functions such as acquisition of multi-sensor/multi-platform/multi-temporal geospatial data such that diverse members will be able to build interoperable systems; and develop new AI-based methods for the reconstruction and labelling of physical locations/object space from diverse geospatial data will unlock significant potential for geospatial data analytics. Through a Center planning meeting, The Ohio State University, Purdue University, and Saint Louis University faculty and administrators will engage a broad spectrum of public and private entities to identify and discuss collective needs with the goal of creating a viable research roadmap and associated research thrusts in which partners are willing to participate and invest. Topics and potential Center research thrusts will be discussed at the meeting, and those of highest importance to industry will be identified upon which a viable Center can be created. Broader impacts of the work include increased economic productivity and integration of the economic sectors that use or wish to use georeferencing; workforce training where students participate in industry-relevant, basic, pre-competitive research projects proposed by university faculty; the engagement of underrepresented groups via various partnerships with institutional entities focused in recruiting and retraining students from underserved populations; and outreach to the public and K-12. 

Industry-university cooperative research centers, like the three-Site Center jointly proposed to be focused on georeferencing in the environment and geospatial techniques and applications by The Ohio State University, Purdue University, and Saint Louis University are powerful partnerships between universities; the private sector; government; non-profits; and local communities. These Centers operate as consortia where university faculty and students perform fundamental research that addresses collective industry and community needs and where projects are funded by membership fees and other financial contributions from Center members. In this construct, the intellectual power; infrastructure; and student talent of universities is focused on real world problems of critical interest of a segment of the economy in need of innovation to overcome conceptual and technological hurdles that individual entities are unable to overcome themselves. The planning meeting proposed will bring together interested parties to hear proto-Center leadership describe the Center’s value proposition and potential return-on-investment of those entities wishing to become members of the Center. Those at the planning meeting will also help the Center create a research road map and research thrusts that best address the most pressing needs of the collective membership in the Center.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
IUCRC Planning Grant:  The Ohio State University?s Center for Accurate Georeferencing of the Environment (CAGE) was a one-year project that investigated various industries? needs and pain-points, exploring industry?s interest in a collaborative research consortium formed by three universities.

Background

In the past ten years, ?location-aware? datasets and applications based on geospatial technologies have revolutionized the way we live, enabling advances in transportation (e.g., connected and autonomous vehicles), health care (e.g., to monitor and curtail the spread of diseases such as COVID-19 and telehealth), defense (intelligence, navigation, targeting, field operations), precision agriculture, smart cities, infrastructure monitoring, computer/cell phone systems, and the internet of things. Geospatial science and technologies and geo-data are used across the entire economy. NIST estimates that a GPS outage could potentially have an economic impact of $1 billion a day. Historically, the government was the main user of geospatial data, for military and civilian projects and science, and provided leadership by developing standards and requirements. However, the civilian market, in particular the consumer segment, have now become the main user, with the military?s share estimated to be less than a percent. And the market is growing: the revenue from the sale of GPS or GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System) equipment was estimated to be $70 B in 2019 and is predicted to show a 16% annual growth rate for the next decade. The US still accounts for about one-fourth of revenues, but is expected to shrink to 20%, while Asia-Pacific region is projected to gain market share of 33% by 2029.

Challenge

The evolution of the geospatial science and engineering landscape over the past three decades has created systemic vulnerabilities for both commercial and government agency productivity. Public funding that served to develop, maintain, and disseminate geospatial reference standards has decreased dramatically, while private sector applications that build on them have increased exponentially, such that entire market sectors (e.g., map production, digital terrain creation, city modeling) have internalized outdated geospatial processing protocols, methods, and data. The growing volume and accuracy of data produced by powerful sensors on a variety of platforms present both a challenge and an opportunity for the sector to leverage information at a new scale. The industry at large seeks leadership and guidelines on how to standardize geospatial data which could serve the entire geospatial ecosystem.  However, no single firm is positioned or incentivized to develop unilaterally these foundations. Therefore, pre-competitive research and development on geospatial data extraction, standardization, and analytics, would allow the sector to avert a productivity and innovation bottleneck that threatens both economic development and public safety.

Proposition

The proposed Center for Accurate Georeferencing of the Environment (CAGE) will integrate the capabilities of three universities (The Ohio State University, OSU; Purdue University, PU; and Saint Louis University, SLU) to advance geospatial research directed by a consortium of companies and agencies. We anticipate that this industry-university collaboration will advance geospatial data/metadata creation and usage, streamline extraction of geospatial intelligence and applications, strengthen the ecosystem of innovation within the geospatial industry, and immerse students and working professionals in next-generation geospatial skills. Our vision is for CAGE to be a crucible for convergent research collaborations in geospatial technologies that accelerate innovation and economic competitiveness.

Focus Areas

  • First, foundational research on GPS/GNSS-based and alternative AI-based navigation and mapping technologies will advance the geospatial data referencing platforms upon which commercial innovation depends.
  • In addition, the refinement of geospatial data standards and best practices for functions such as acquisition of multi-sensor/multi-platform/multi-temporal geospatial data and crowdsourcing of geospatial data will allow diverse members of the industry to build interoperable systems.
  • Finally, research into new, AI-based methods for the reconstruction and labelling of physical locations/object space from diverse geospatial data will unlock significant potential for geospatial data analytics. The introduction of artificial intelligence to the geospatial data analysis pipeline will give us the ability to learn and adapt to dynamically changing environments.

Objectives

The Industry?University Cooperative Research Centers (IUCRC) program accelerates the impact of basic research by fostering close relationships among industry innovators, world-class academic teams, and government leaders. IUCRCs help corporate partners and government agencies connect directly and efficiently with university researchers to achieve three objectives:

  • Conduct high-impact research to meet shared industrial needs in companies of all sizes;
  • Enhance U.S. global leadership in driving innovative technology development, and;
  • Identify, mentor, and develop a diverse high-tech, exceptionally skilled workforce.

Achievements

In the course of the project, major accomplishments included:

  • Conducted 100+ interviews with stakeholders from 70+ organizations;
  • Engaged faculty at three universities to prepare 38 concept papers;
  • Organized the IUCRC Planning Workshop at OSU, May 25-26, 2022, bringing together 60 attendees from companies, university researchers, and government representatives, including NSF program officers;
  • Developed and submitted to NSF the Phase 1 proposal on December 2022, with commitments from 12 organizations to become paying CAGE members if selected.

Last Modified: 03/29/2023
Modified by: Ayman Habib
